member.name: M:ServiceStack.Auth.AuthHttpGateway.DownloadYammerUserInfo(System.String)
member.summary: Download Yammer User Info given its ID.
member.returns: The User info in JSON format.

remarks.para: Yammer provides a method to retrieve current user information via "https://www.yammer.com/api/v1/users/current.json".
However, to ensure consistency with the rest of the Auth codebase, the explicit URL will be used, where [:id] denotes the User ID: "https://www.yammer.com/api/v1/users/[:id].json"
Refer to: https://developer.yammer.com/restapi/ for full documentation.

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Auth.YammerAuthProvider
member.summary: The ServiceStack Yammer OAuth provider.

remarks.para: This provider is loosely based on the existing ServiceStack's Facebook OAuth provider.
For the full info on Yammer's OAuth2 authentication flow, refer to: https://developer.yammer.com/authentication/#a-oauth2

Note: Add these to your application / web config settings under appSettings and replace values as appropriate.
<!-- ServiceStack Yammer OAuth config --> <add key="oauth.yammer.ClientId" value=""/> <add key="oauth.yammer.ClientSecret" value=""/> <add key="oauth.yammer.AccessTokenUrl" value="https://www.yammer.com/oauth2/access_token.json"/> <add key="oauth.yammer.CallbackUrl" value="~/"/> <add key="oauth.yammer.PreAuthUrl" value="https://www.yammer.com/dialog/oauth"/> <add key="oauth.yammer.Realm" value="https://www.yammer.com"/> <add key="oauth.yammer.RedirectUrl" value="~/auth/yammer"/>

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgery
member.summary: Provides access to the anti-forgery system, which provides protection against Cross-site Request Forgery (XSRF, also called CSRF) attacks.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgery.GetHtml
member.summary: Generates an anti-forgery token for this request. This token can be validated by calling the Validate() method.
member.returns: An HTML string corresponding to an <input type="hidden"> element. This element should be put inside a <form>.
member.remarks: This method has a side effect: it may set a response cookie.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgery.GetTokens(System.String,System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary: Generates an anti-forgery token pair (cookie and form token) for this request. This method is similar to GetHtml(), but this method gives the caller control over how to persist the returned values. To validate these tokens, call the appropriate overload of Validate.
member.param: The anti-forgery token - if any - that already existed for this request. May be null. The anti-forgery system will try to reuse this cookie value when generating a matching form token.

Will contain a new cookie value if the old cookie token was null or invalid. If this value is non-null when the method completes, the caller must persist this value in the form of a response cookie, and the existing cookie value should be discarded. If this value is null when the method completes, the existing cookie value was valid and needn't be modified.
The value that should be stored in the <form>. The caller should take care not to accidentally swap the cookie and form tokens.
member.remarks: Unlike the GetHtml() method, this method has no side effect. The caller is responsible for setting the response cookie and injecting the returned form token as appropriate.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgery.Validate
member.summary: Validates an anti-forgery token that was supplied for this request. The anti-forgery token may be generated by calling GetHtml().
member.remarks: Throws an HttpAntiForgeryException if validation fails.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgery.Validate(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Validates an anti-forgery token pair that was generated by the GetTokens method.
member.param: The token that was supplied in the request cookie.
The token that was supplied in the request form body.
member.remarks: Throws an HttpAntiForgeryException if validation fails.

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgeryConfig
member.summary: Provides programmatic configuration for the anti-forgery token system.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgeryConfig.AdditionalDataProvider
member.summary: Specifies an object that can provide additional data to put into all generated tokens and that can validate additional data in incoming tokens.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgeryConfig.CookieName
member.summary: Specifies the name of the cookie that is used by the anti-forgery system.
member.remarks: If an explicit name is not provided, the system will automatically generate a name.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgeryConfig.RequireSsl
member.summary: Specifies whether SSL is required for the anti-forgery system to operate. If this setting is 'true' and a non-SSL request comes into the system, all anti-forgery APIs will fail.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgeryConfig.SuppressIdentityHeuristicChecks
member.summary: Specifies whether the anti-forgery system should skip checking for conditions that might indicate misuse of the system. Please use caution when setting this switch, as improper use could open security holes in the application.
member.remarks: Setting this switch will disable several checks, including: - Identity.IsAuthenticated = true without Identity.Name being set - special-casing claims-based identities

member.name: P:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.AntiForgeryConfig.UniqueClaimTypeIdentifier
member.summary: If claims-based authorization is in use, specifies the claim type from the identity that is used to uniquely identify the user. If this property is set, all claims-based identities must return unique values for this claim type.
member.remarks: If claims-based authorization is in use and this property has not been set, the anti-forgery system will automatically look for claim types "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier" and "http://schemas.microsoft.com/accesscontrolservice/2010/07/claims/identityprovider".

member.name: T:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.IAntiForgeryAdditionalDataProvider
member.summary: Allows providing or validating additional custom data for anti-forgery tokens. For example, the developer could use this to supply a nonce when the token is generated, then he could validate the nonce when the token is validated.
member.remarks: The anti-forgery system already embeds the client's username within the generated tokens. This interface provides and consumes supplemental data. If an incoming anti-forgery token contains supplemental data but no additional data provider is configured, the supplemental data will not be validated.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.IAntiForgeryAdditionalDataProvider.GetAdditionalData(System.Web.HttpContextBase)
member.summary: Provides additional data to be stored for the anti-forgery tokens generated during this request.
member.returns: Supplemental data to embed within the anti-forgery token.

member.name: M:ServiceStack.Html.AntiXsrf.IAntiForgeryAdditionalDataProvider.ValidateAdditionalData(System.Web.HttpContextBase,System.String)
member.summary: Validates additional data that was embedded inside an incoming anti-forgery token.
member.param: Supplemental data that was embedded within the token.
member.returns: True if the data is valid; false if the data is invalid.

member.name: P:ServiceStack.MiniProfiler.Profiler.Settings.RouteBasePath
member.summary: The path under which ALL routes are registered in, defaults to the application root. For example, "~/myDirectory/" would yield "/myDirectory/ssr-includes.js" rather than just "/mini-profiler-includes.js" Any setting here should be in APP RELATIVE FORM, e.g. "~/myDirectory/"

member.name: P:ServiceStack.MiniProfiler.Profiler.Settings.Storage
member.summary: Understands how to save and load MiniProfilers. Used for caching between when a profiling session ends and results can be fetched to the client, and for showing shared, full-page results.
member.remarks: The normal profiling session life-cycle is as follows: 1) request begins 2) profiler is started 3) normal page/controller/request execution 4) profiler is stopped 5) profiler is cached with 's implementation of 6) request ends 7) page is displayed and profiling results are ajax-fetched down, pulling cached results from 's implementation of

member.name: T:ServiceStack.SuppressFormsAuthenticationRedirectModule
member.summary:
This class interecepts 401 requests and changes them to 402 errors. When this happens the FormAuthentication module will no longer hijack it and redirect back to login because it is a 402 error, not a 401. When the request ends, this class sets the status code back to 401 and everything works as it should.
PathToSupress is the path inside your website where the above swap should happen.
If you can build for .net 4.5, you do not have to do this swap. You can take advantage of a new flag (SuppressFormsAuthenticationRedirect) that tells the FormAuthenticationModule to not redirect, which also means you will not need the EndRequest code.

member.summary:
Create a new Markdown instance and optionally load options from a configuration file. There they should be stored in the appSettings section, available options are:
Markdown.StrictBoldItalic (true/false) Markdown.EmptyElementSuffix (">" or " />" without the quotes) Markdown.LinkEmails (true/false) Markdown.AutoNewLines (true/false) Markdown.AutoHyperlink (true/false) Markdown.EncodeProblemUrlCharacters (true/false)

member.name: M:MarkdownSharp.Markdown.TokenizeHTML(System.String)
member.summary: returns an array of HTML tokens comprising the input string. Each token is either a tag (possibly with nested, tags contained therein, such as <a href="<MTFoo>">, or a run of text between tags. Each element of the array is a two-element array; the first is either 'tag' or 'text'; the second is the actual value.

member.summary: Within tags -- meaning between < and > -- encode [\ ` * _] so they don't conflict with their use in Markdown for code, italics and strong. We're replacing each such character with its corresponding hash value; this is likely overkill, but it should prevent us from colliding with the escape values by accident.
